main_text:
Aristotle's Treatment of Mathematical Objects
7. Aristotle's Treatment of Mathematical Objects


The account here of Aristotle on the status of mathematical objects
will center on five concepts, which Aristotle uses in his discussions:
‘abstraction’ or ‘taking away’ or
‘removal’ or ‘subtraction’
(aphairesis), ‘precision’
(akribeia), ‘as separated’
(hôs kekhôrismenon),
‘qua’ or ‘in the respect that’
(hêi), and ‘intelligible
matter’ (noêtikê hylê).
Principal sources are the Posterior Analytics, De
Anima iii.6-8, Metaphysics iii.2, vi.1, vii.10-11, ix.9,
x.1-2, xi.2-3, 7, xiii.1-3, Physics ii.2.
hierarchy_title: Aristotle and Mathematics || Aristotle's Treatment of Mathematical Objects
